- Identify the infected or contaminating partner(s) and propose screening, diagnosis and/or probabilistic treatment;

- Systematically offer :

- HIV serology,

- treponemal test,

- hepatitis B serology

- Urinary or genital PCR for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis,

- Pharyngeal and anal PCR according to sexual practices

- Emphasise the risks of recontamination (education).

- Consider PrEP (Pre-Exposure Prophylaxis) type treatment against HIV if you take risks too regularly

question.title: What should you do when caring for a partner or partners who has a sexually transmitted infection (STI)?
question.description: Identify the infected or contaminating partner(s) and propose screening, diagnosis and/or probabilistic treatment;

option_a.title: Only offer HIV serology and hepatitis B serology
option_a.description: This option is only partially correct, as it does not mention other necessary tests such as treponemal test and urinary or genital PCR.

option_b.title: All of the above
option_b.description: This option is correct, as it includes all the necessary tests for screening, diagnosis, and probabilistic treatment.

option_c.title: Only propose PrEP treatment if the partner has a history of high-risk behavior
option_c.description: This option is incorrect, as PrEP treatment should be considered for all partners at risk, regardless of behavior.

option_d.title: Emphasize the risks of recontamination through education, but do not offer any testing
option_d.description: This option is incorrect, as education on recontamination risks is important, but testing is also necessary for diagnosis and treatment.

correct_option.title: B
correct_option.description: This consists only of the letter B
